quizzes.question: Which file is placed in a directory to make it a package?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Packaging[/h1]

[b][/b]In Python, the term [b]packaging [/b]refers to putting modules you have written in a standard format, so that other programmers can install and use them with ease. 
This involves use of the modules [b]setuptools [/b]and [b]distutils[/b]. 
The first step in packaging is to organize existing files correctly. Place all of the files you want to put in a library in the same parent directory. This directory should also contain a file called [b]__init__.py[/b], which can be blank but must be present in the directory.
This directory goes into another directory containing the readme and license, as well as an important file called [b]setup.py[/b]. 
[b]Example directory structure:[/b] [code format="raw"]SoloLearn/
   LICENSE.txt
   README.txt
   [b]setup.py[/b]
   sololearn/
      [b]__init__.py[/b]
      sololearn.py
      sololearn2.py[/code]
[note]You can place as many script files in the directory as you need.[/note]

quizzes.question: What is the command used for building a source distribution?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Packaging[/h1]

The next step in packaging is to write the [b]setup.py[/b] file. 
This contains information necessary to assemble the package so it can be uploaded to [b]PyPI [/b]and installed with [b]pip[/b] (name, version, etc.).
Example of a [b]setup.py[/b] file: [code format="raw"]from distutils.core import setup

setup(
   name='SoloLearn', 
   version='0.1dev',
   packages=['sololearn',],
   license='MIT', 
   long_description=open('README.txt').read(),
)[/code]
After creating the [b]setup.py[/b] file, upload it to [b]PyPI[/b], or use the command line to create a binary distribution (an executable installer).
To build a source distribution, use the command line to navigate to the directory containing setup.py, and run the command [b]python setup.py sdist[/b].
Run[b] python setup.py bdist[/b] or, for Windows,[b] python setup.py bdist_wininst [/b]to build a binary distribution. 
Use [b]python setup.py register[/b], followed by[b] python setup.py sdist upload[/b] to upload a package.
[note]Finally, install a package with [b]python setup.py install[/b].[/note]
